importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the announcement of the new presidential election results in Bolivia, signaling a political shift and the beginning of a new administration.
The date of the August general election in Bolivia, which saw a major defeat for the MAS party, set the stage for the subsequent run-off election and the eventual rise of Rodrigo Paz as president.

The end of outgoing President Luis Arce’s term on November 8 marks a constitutional transition point in Bolivia’s political cycle, with the new administration beginning its mandate after his departure.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2013 to 2024 saw a significant decline in energy revenues for Bolivia due to reduced gas sector expansion under Evo Morales, leading to a worsening economic crisis and foreign exchange shortages.

keyTakeAways: Bolivians have elected Rodrigo Paz of the centre-right Christian Democratic Party (PDC) as president, ending 20 years of MAS party rule.
Paz won 54.5% of the vote in the run-off, defeating Jorge Quiroga (45.4%), with 97% of ballots counted.
Paz, 58, is the son of former left-wing President Jaime Zamora and has a background in local politics, including roles as city councillor, mayor of Tarija, and senator.
Paz has pledged a 'capitalism for all' approach, including tax cuts, tariff reductions, and decentralisation of government.
The MAS party suffered a major defeat after Evo Morales was barred from running due to term limits and party affiliation issues, and Luis Arce stepped aside due to political infighting.
The country faces deep economic crisis: inflation at nearly 25%, fuel and food shortages, and a drop in energy revenues from $6.1 billion (2013) to $1.6 billion (2024).
Despite the victory, Paz faces opposition from Evo Morales, who remains popular, especially among Indigenous communities.
Vice-president Edmand Lara called for unity, price stabilization, and an end to corruption.
Paz has not clearly committed to ending the costly fuel subsidy, only suggesting it may be limited to vulnerable populations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Bolivians have elected Rodrigo Paz of the centre-right Christian Democratic Party (PDC) as president in a decisive run-off vote, ending 20 years of rule by the Movement for Socialism (MAS) party. With 54.5% of the vote, Paz outpaced right-wing candidate Jorge Quiroga (45.4%), following a major MAS defeat after Evo Morales was barred from running due to term limits and political disagreements. The new administration faces significant economic challenges, including near-25% inflation, critical fuel and food shortages, and a sharp decline in energy revenues from $6.1 billion in 2013 to $1.6 billion in 2024. Paz, the son of former President Jaime Zamora, has pledged a 'capitalism for all' agenda with tax cuts, tariff reductions, and decentralisation, but remains uncertain on continuing the costly fuel subsidy. Despite the political shift, opposition from Evo Morales—still popular among Indigenous communities—remains a major challenge. Vice-president Edmand Lara called for national unity, price stabilization, and an end to corruption.
title: Bolivia elects centre-right Rodrigo Paz as president
